Thursday's assembly was devoted to the initiation of the
newly elected members of Pi
Delta Epsilon, the honorary
journalistic fraternity. The following men were announced :
Maurice Chassin, Gordon Biggs,
Hyman Levin, Charles H. Davis,
Gordon Green, Morton Gutkin
and Haskell Milestone.
Isadore
Gutman
presiding,
urged a greater interest on the
part of the student body in the
Hopkins publications. He introduced Dean Berry who spoke
briefly of the power of journalism as the fourth estate in society, and mentioned several personal journalistic experiences.
Mitchell Speaks

Dr. Broadus Mitchell, the next
speaker, urged a corporate interest in student affairs. He then
talked at length on the necessity
of facing facts in life and doing
what is the honest and decent
thing, even though adverse criticisms may be encountered.
In May, 1931, the Hopkins
chapter of Pi Delta Epsilon was
reorganized with seven charter
members, six of whom were
graduated last June. The original chapter received its charter
in 1922 and was disbanded in
1926.
The chief purpose of the fraternity, which takes its membership from leaders on the three
university publications, is to recognize journalistic ability and to
form an organization of journalistic leaders who can aid in _raising the standards of the J. H. U.
publications.
Charter Group

The charter members include
I. Cyrus Gutman, who is the incumbent president; Robert Miller, George Dowell, Townsend
Parks, Wilson Rutherford, and
Gus Burk.
Other officers of Pi Delta Epsilon are R. McD. Ness, secretary; Daniel Miller, vice-president; Eugene Pessagno, treasurer.

The Black and Blue started

occasions that the Black and
Blue defenders were forced to
show their wares, their perform
ance was erratic.
At times Swarthmore's play
were completely bottled up
while, on other occasions, Hop
kins cleared the ball miserably
Reynolds, who started the gam
at cover point, and Merriken both
covered their men well.
Maroon Goals Unearned

mare's goals was really earned
It was made by McCord on a fif
teen yard heave with Fritz Stude
completely screened.

roon man accidentally kicked in

Tradition, Bah!
TRADITION be hanged!

Banquet season must be abolished!
The demonstration of amazing
as1111mty and callosity on the
parts of the collegiate-minded
freshmen and sophomore leaders
in the 1932 banquet season battle
has been ample ground on which
to suggest the abolition of the
traditional event.
This paper demands that the
Student Council conduct a vote in
the freshman class on the question of the retention or abolition
of banquet season. We advise
that only freshmen be permitted
to vote and that ballots be signed
by each voter.
The group favoring the annual
pre-banquet warfare must not be
permitted to dictate. If the plurality votes its abolition then let
Student Council grant that officially without hesitation.
In an editorial last week we
"heartily endorsed" banquet season, admitting that it is incongruous with the general atmosphere of the campus, on the
ground that it is the lone surviving undergraduate tradition. We
took that stand because we felt
that each class would minimize
vandalism and personal injury
this year. Our hope, we sadly
state, was completely shattered
as early as noon last Monday.

have divided the spoils of office.

Editor, The News-Letter,
